reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe giving value before requesting action at phase transitions. works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate) says 'open with recognition, not instruction -- show the host what they already provided or accomplished before asking for new input.' works-0900-001 (Gift-Before-Gate) says 'before requesting any host action, the platform must deliver something of tangible value.' The mechanism differs -- works-001 operates through cognitive coherence (System 1 associative network), works-0900-001 operates through reciprocal obligation (Cialdini's uninvited gift) -- but the UX prescription is identical: value before request at every transition.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kahneman explains WHY value-before-request works (System 1 coherence enables System 2 engagement). Cialdini explains HOW to make it work (gifts create obligation to reciprocate with action). Combined insight: the gift IS the System 1 coherence signal. A personalized, relevant gift at a phase transition simultaneously passes the trust gate (System 1 approves) AND creates reciprocal obligation (Cialdini's rule activates). Two independent theoretical frameworks converge on the same design pattern.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the human-to-digital handoff problem. works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust Through Continuity Priming) says 'the platform must feel like opening a letter from someone you just spoke with.' works-0900-004 (Visible Reciprocity Ledger) extends this into the active lease where the digital platform must maintain the trust that the human agent built. The new element adds the specific mechanism of visible reciprocity tracking for three-party ghost roommate arrangements -- a scenario the original element did not contemplate.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: works-004 uses Kahneman's priming research to show that the platform must inherit trust from the agent. works-0900-004 uses Cialdini's web of indebtedness to show that the platform must actively maintain trust through visible reciprocity tracking. Combined: the platform must both inherit trust (onboarding) and maintain trust (active lease) through different but complementary mechanisms. Priming bridges the gap; reciprocity sustains the bridge.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the efficiency gap between phone conversation and platform interaction. works-003 (Match Platform Speed to Conversational Speed) prescribes that 'information conveyed in 7 seconds of speech should be capturable in under 15 seconds on the platform.' communicates-0900-001 (Gift-First Information Hierarchy) prescribes that value information (gifts) must occupy 60% of screen space with requests at 40%. The speed element says 'be as fast as the call'; the hierarchy element says 'show what I give you before what I ask.' Both reduce friction at the same interaction points.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kahneman's cognitive speed research underlies works-003. Cialdini's gift-before-request sequence underlies communicates-0900-001. Combined insight: speed AND sequence both matter. The platform must be fast (works-003) AND lead with gifts (communicates-0900-001). A fast platform that leads with requests is still wrong. A gift-first platform that is slow still fails. Both conditions must hold simultaneously.

reinforcements.similarity: Both address the emotional vulnerability of the onboarding transition. works-004 focuses on the trust mechanism (continuity priming). feels-0900-002 focuses on the emotional target (relief through recognition). Same phase, same problem, complementary lenses: one says 'bridge trust with familiar signals,' the other says 'make the host feel relief by showing they are already known.'
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Kahneman (priming) plus Cialdini (gift of pre-filled data) converge on the same onboarding design: show the host their information from the call as the first thing they see. The trust bridge IS the emotional relief mechanism. Seeing 'Bryant mentioned your Brooklyn room' simultaneously primes trust (works-004) and delivers the gift of recognition (feels-0900-002).

contradictions.conflict: looks-0900-003 (Reciprocity Health Indicator) specifies --success-green (#4B47CE) for healthy status indicators, following the production style guide. However, #4B47CE is purple, not green. Using purple for 'success/healthy' status in a traffic-light indicator (green/amber/red) may confuse users who have strong cultural associations between green and 'good.' The proposed status colors from Paula Scher's audit (--status-warning: #C4841D, --status-error: #C53030) are not yet in production.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The production style guide explicitly maps --success-green to #4B47CE (purple) and states 'NO GREEN, NO YELLOW' in protocol components. Paula Scher's proposed revisions acknowledge this as a problem ('Current contrast: ~3.0:1, FAIL') but the proposals are NOT YET IN PRODUCTION. The new element follows the production guide but acknowledges the tension.
contradictions.recommendation: Flag for design review: consider whether the active lease health indicator should use the production palette (all purple) or the proposed status palette (purple/amber/red). For the UI elements in Layer 8, use the production palette with a note that the proposed status colors would be preferable if/when adopted.

extensions.gap_filled: The library had no element addressing fallback flows when hosts decline or hesitate at high-commitment gates. works-0900-003 (Rejection-Then-Retreat) provides the first design pattern for graceful degradation from full requests to smaller commitments. This covers listing_creation (full wizard -> quick start), proposal_mgmt (accept -> counter-suggest), and retention (full renewal -> month-to-month). No existing element addresses this interaction pattern.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong evidence from Cialdini (tripled compliance in zoo experiment) and strong behavioral evidence from Sherene's call (she neither accepts nor rejects -- she occupies a middle ground the platform has no mechanism to support). Single lens but high theoretical confidence.

extensions.gap_filled: The library had no element specifically addressing multi-party reciprocity tracking in ghost roommate arrangements. works-0900-004 (Visible Reciprocity Ledger) is the first element to address the three-party dynamics unique to ghost roommate hosting. This extends the library's coverage to the highest-complexity hosting scenario.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Cialdini reciprocity) but the ghost roommate scenario is a real, documented arrangement type with specific operational needs. The evidence from Sherene's call provides rich behavioral grounding.

extensions.gap_filled: The library had no element addressing the weekly guest-to-guest transition in ghost roommate arrangements. behaves-0900-004 (Thursday Handoff Interaction) provides the first structured interaction protocol for the recurring handoff between rotating guests. This is entirely new territory for the element library.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens but addresses a concrete operational need described in detail in Sherene's call (19:13-19:58). High implementation relevance.

extensions.gap_filled: The library had elements about depleted users (works-002) and System 1 trust gates (works-001) but no explicit interaction pattern for detecting hesitation and offering a reduced commitment. behaves-0900-002 (Rejection-Then-Retreat State Machine) extends the library with a specific state machine pattern (FULL REQUEST -> RETREAT -> SAVED) that is implementable as a front-end interaction.
extensions.confidence_note: Strong theoretical backing from Cialdini's research (17% to 50% compliance increase). Single lens but the pattern is well-established in behavioral science and maps directly to observable platform behaviors (wizard abandonment, proposal non-response).

extensions.gap_filled: The library had no element addressing the emotional design of daily payment notifications during active lease. feels-0900-004 (Daily Payment as Continuous Reassurance) fills a gap in the emotional arc between onboarding and retention, providing guidance for the most frequent platform touchpoint during active hosting.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. The daily payment cadence is described in the Sherene call (07:21-07:39) and theoretically grounded in Cialdini's temporal proximity principle. The emotional target (calm) is well-calibrated to the active lease context.

new_tokens_flagged: --gift-container-bg (rgb(252, 250, 255) with left border in --secondary-purple) -- proposed in looks-0900-001. Not a named token. Closest existing: --bg-off-white which is the same color value but without the border treatment.

--gift-shadow (0 2px 8px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.12)) -- proposed in looks-0900-001. Not a named token. Closest existing: --shadow-purple-sm (0 2px 4px rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.2)) which uses a different purple and is slightly more opaque.
--avatar-warm-shadow (0 4px 12px rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15)) -- proposed in looks-0900-002. Not in token system. Larger and softer than --shadow-purple-sm.
--notification-accent-width (3px) -- proposed in looks-0900-005. Between --border-width-thick (2px) and no existing wider option.
--progress-bar-height (4px) -- proposed in looks-0900-005. Not in the sizing token system.
--status-dot-size (10px) -- proposed in looks-0900-003. Not in the token system.
--status-warning (#C4841D) -- used in looks-0900-003. From Paula Scher's proposed palette, NOT YET IN PRODUCTION.
--status-error (#C53030) -- used in looks-0900-003. From Paula Scher's proposed palette, NOT YET IN PRODUCTION.
token_compliance.recommendation: Add --gift-container-bg and --gift-shadow as component-level tokens (they represent a new pattern type: gift containers). Add --notification-accent-width and --progress-bar-height as sizing tokens. Defer --avatar-warm-shadow until more elements need avatar-specific shadow treatment. For status colors, continue using production palette (#4B47CE for success) and note the proposed Paula Scher colors as aspirational improvements pending team review.

arc_conflicts: No direct conflicts detected in this run's emotional arc. The progression from curiosity (discovery) through relief (onboarding) to confidence (pricing) to calm (active lease) to gratitude (retention) is internally consistent and follows the natural arc of increasing commitment and decreasing anxiety.

Minor tension: the evaluation phase has both 'curiosity' (from feels-0900-001) and 'growing obligation' (from the Layer 0 journey context). These are compatible but the feels element should acknowledge that obligation and curiosity coexist at evaluation -- the host is curious AND beginning to feel obligated by the gifts received.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc is coherent end-to-end. It follows a classic trust-building progression: curiosity hooks the host, relief converts them, confidence commits them, calm sustains them, and gratitude retains them. The reciprocity lens adds a unique layer: at each phase, the target emotion is created by a specific gift (knowledge gift -> curiosity, recognition gift -> relief, pricing gift -> confidence, payment gift -> calm, cumulative gift -> gratitude). This gift-to-emotion mapping is the most actionable contribution of this run to the emotional arc.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The works elements do not include a process pattern for the partner-approval handoff. Sherene repeatedly mentions needing to 'talk to my partner' (21:04). The platform has no mechanism to support this secondary decision-maker who was not on the call and has not received any reciprocal gifts.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Design a process pattern for partner-inclusive decision-making: how does the platform extend the reciprocity chain to a secondary decision-maker who was not part of the original gift exchange? This could be a separate 'Partner Briefing' gift: a shareable summary that gives the partner enough information (and enough uninvited gifts) to feel the same obligation Sherene feels.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The looks elements define visual patterns for gift containers, guest profiles, and status indicators, but do not include a visual pattern for the rejection-then-retreat UI (behaves-0900-002). The state machine described in Layer 4 needs a corresponding visual treatment: how does the full wizard dim? How does the retreat card appear? What does the saved state look like?
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Design visual treatments for the three states of the rejection-then-retreat pattern: FULL REQUEST (normal), RETREAT (dimmed wizard + rising retreat card), and SAVED (confirmation with persistent progress indicator).

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The feels elements cover discovery through retention but do not explicitly address the emotional state of the host during the partner-approval waiting period. Between Sherene's call and her return (after discussing with partner), there is an emotional gap: the obligation is decaying without new gifts, and the partner may be introducing skepticism.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Design an emotional element for the 'waiting period' between initial engagement and partner-approved commitment. What gifts can the platform deliver during this waiting period to maintain the reciprocity chain? How does the platform address the partner's skepticism without having a direct relationship with them?
